description.narrative: The Save the Children Programme on Strengthening the Multi-sectoral national child protection system in Zanzibar aims to ensure that all children especially 10% of the most vulnerable children in Zanzibar are protected from all forms of abuse and exploitation by 2014 through implementation of a state wide multi-sectoral collaboration with civil society.

The Save the Children programme on "Establishing a Multi-stakeholder Child Protection System in Zanzibar has been funded by the Embassy of Sweden since 2011. Annual reports and various field visits done by the Programme Officers, Controllers and Political Officer have shown that there is a clear direction towards achieveing the objectives set at both outcome and impact level. There are significant and very relevant qualitative results at both the national, district and Shehia level. It is clear that the Government and other key stakeholders are recognising the benefits of the multisectoral approach in addressing child protection matters.
Furthermore, the project has demonstrated that the Government is consistently and gradually taking over coordination and ownership of the child protection mechanisms. The programme is suggested to be extended for the period January - June 2015 in order to provide an opportunity for a development of a comprehensive child rights governanace and child protection programme and systematic phaseout of the current support. During this period the key focus will be on strengthening the enabling environment for sustainability of the programme interventions through more focused advocacy activities, strengthening accountability and child safeguarding and children's councils, documentation of results and more indepth work with media partners to promote increased knowledge about child rights and legal provisions for general public, victims and potential victims.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: This programme was extended to 30th June 2016 in order to provide space for the completion of the SC Country Strategy Plan 2016 - 2018. The programme was originally intended to be phased out by 30th June 2015. During the period from January 2015 to June 2016, the following results have been achieved: 1) Increased capacity at One Stop Centres (OSCs) through appointment and training of National Coordinator and 6 Centre Coordinators and commitment from the MoH to fund these staff positions. 2) Renovation of the National Child Protection Unit and TOR for each of the 10 National Social Welfare Officers. 3) Engagement on child rights and child protection with law enforcement professionals from both Common Law courts together with Kadhi’s Courts. 4) Establishment of the National Technical Committee on Positive Discipline and Positive Parenting and its three Sub-Committees. 5) Development of the positive discipline manual for teachers in government and private schools, the first ever Zanzibar Children’s Council manual and a positive parenting manual. 6) Initial steps on a road map for care reform as well as a recent statement by the Director of the Department of Social Welfare (DSW) that no child can now be enrolled in a home without the approval by the DSW Director, as a custodian of all children’s homes in Zanzibar. 7) New curricula on child rights and child protection developed and integrated into the Degree in Social Work at Zanzibar University. 8) Event on March 3 celebrating six years of supporting the development of a comprehensive and sustainable child protection system in Zanzibar. All partners attended the much appreciated event and presented progress within all of the 11 components of the Child Protection Ssystem.
A few challenges were noted during this reporting period that will continue to be adressed in consequent periods. An assessment of the 6 one stop centres ( OSC) concluded that the department of social welfare ( DSW) did not have enough human resources to comply with OSC minimum standards. It was therefore decided that the overall coordination of the OSCs should be under the management of the Ministry of Health. The MOH thereafter allocated Human Resources to the centres. However, since this was not part of the MoH budget, these posts could not be included in the payroll, therefore SC took the initiative to fund these appiontments through a volunteer stipend agree with the MoH on a temporary basis. This was highly appreciated by the MOH. In its Memorandum of Understanding with SC, the MoH is committed to ensure that the 7 positions are on the Government payroll during the onset of the financial year 2016/2017. This is considered to be an example of lessons learnt and the importance of recognition of ownership by the Government.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
